We have enlisted hundreds of friends -- biblical scholars, theologians, homileticians and pastors dedicated to the craft of biblical preaching -- to provide you timely, compelling and trustworthy content." /><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width"><style>

                    <h3>Festival in D.C.</h3><p>Register today for the 2018 Festival of Homiletics, May 21-25, in Washington, D.C.</p><p><a href="https://www.festivalofhomiletics.com/register.aspx?m=4436">Read More</a></p></div>

                    <div id="lectionary_icon" class="lectionary_icon">
                    <p class="icon1 selected alternate_icon1"><a href="?lectionary_calendar_id=950&lectionary=rcl" target="_top">Fifth Sunday in Lent</a></p></div>
                </div>
                <div id="from_ls_text"><a href="http://luthersem.edu" id="from_ls"><span class="ls_from_left">&nbsp;</span><span class="ls_from_text">from Luther Seminary</span><span class="ls_from_right">&nbsp;</span></a></div>
                <div id="wp_i_c_readings">
                    <div id="RevisedCommonLectionary">
		
                        
                        <div class="reading">
<h2><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3581">Gospel Reading</a></h2>
<p class="verses"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3581">
John 12:20-33 Commentary</a></p>
<p class="author">by <strong>Mary Hinkle Shore</strong></p>
<div class="description"><p>As with nearly every passage in the gospel of John, this reading uses simple vocabulary that is filled with theological content.</p></div>
<p class="read_more"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3581">Commentary</a>
 | <a href="javascript:popup_no_modal('%2fControls%2fright%2ftool_wp_calendar_author_reading%2fload_reading_text.aspx%3freading_id%3d1204','Scripture Reading Text',500,700);">Bible Text</a></p></div>
<div class="reading">
<h2><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3607">1st Reading</a></h2>
<p class="verses"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3607">
Jeremiah 31:31-34 Commentary</a></p>
<p class="author">by <strong>Terence E. Fretheim</strong></p>
<div class="description"><p>The images used in Jeremiah 31 are predominantly familial rather than political or military.<sup>1</sup></p></div>
<p class="read_more"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3607">Commentary</a>
 | <a href="javascript:popup_no_modal('%2fControls%2fright%2ftool_wp_calendar_author_reading%2fload_reading_text.aspx%3freading_id%3d1202','Scripture Reading Text',500,700);">Bible Text</a></p></div>
<div class="reading">
<h2><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3597">Psalm</a></h2>
<p class="verses"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3597">
Psalm 51:1-12 Commentary</a></p>
<p class="author">by <strong>Elizabeth Webb</strong></p>
<div class="description"><p>This is a text that must be handled with care.<sup>1</sup></p></div>
<p class="read_more"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3597">Commentary</a>
 | <a href="javascript:popup_no_modal('%2fControls%2fright%2ftool_wp_calendar_author_reading%2fload_reading_text.aspx%3freading_id%3d1201','Scripture Reading Text',500,700);">Bible Text</a></p></div>
<div class="reading reading-last">
<h2><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3583">2nd Reading</a></h2>
<p class="verses"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3583">
Hebrews 5:5-10 Commentary</a></p>
<p class="author">by <strong>Jennifer T. Kaalund</strong></p>
<div class="description"><p>There are many images of Jesus that have captured our imaginations -- Jesus as a baby, a shepherd, a carpenter, and a teacher.</p></div>
<p class="read_more"><a href="/preaching.aspx?commentary_id=3583">Commentary</a>
 | <a href="javascript:popup_no_modal('%2fControls%2fright%2ftool_wp_calendar_author_reading%2fload_reading_text.aspx%3freading_id%3d1203','Scripture Reading Text',500,700);">Bible Text</a></p></div>

                        <div id="wp_i_c_print">Print:&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="/wp_print_all.aspx?lectionary_calendar_id=950&amp;print_type=text&amp;is_spanish=0">All Texts</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="/wp_print_all.aspx?lectionary_calendar_id=950&amp;print_type=comm&amp;is_spanish=0">All Commentary</a></div>
                        <div id="wp_i_c_feature" class="pen-border wp_i_c_feature">
                        <div class="feature_left pen-border dwp"><h2><a href="/craft.aspx?cat_id=36">Dear Working Preacher</a></h2><div class="icon_wrap" ><p class="feature_title"><a href="/craft.aspx?post=5114">Seeing Jesus</a></p><p class="author_name">by <strong>Karoline Lewis</strong></p><p class="feature_date">March 18, 2018</p><p class="feature_description"><p>&ldquo;Sir, we wish to see Jesus.&rdquo; Do we really? Do we actually want to see Jesus? Or do we pretend, feign interest, when in fact, seeing Jesus just might cause a kind of ...</p>
</p><p class="feature_link"><a href="/craft.aspx?post=5114">Read More</a></p></div></div><div class="feature_right brainwave"><h2><a href="/brainwave.aspx">Sermon Brainwave Podcast</a></h2><div class="icon_wrap"><p class="feature_title"><a href="/brainwave.aspx?podcast_id=993" class="audiolink">SB595 - Fifth Sunday in Lent</a></p><p class="feature_date">March 18, 2018</p><p class="feature_description">Discussion on Revised Common Lectionary texts for Fifth Sunday in Lent (Mar. 18, 2018): (Gospel) John 12:20-33; (1st Reading) Jeremiah 31:31-34; Psalm 51:1-12; (2nd Reading) Hebrews 5:5-10. Recorded at Luther Seminary, Saint Paul, Minn., for WorkingPreacher.org.</p></div></div></div>
